column4: Eye drug maker Akorn to buy rival Hi-Tech Pharmacal for $640 million
column5: Generic drugmaker Akorn Inc will buy rival Hi-Tech Pharmacal Co Inc for $640 million to expand its eye drug portfolio to oral liquids and ointments.

column4: Eye drug firm Akorn to buy rival Hi-Tech Pharmacal for $640 mln
column5: Aug 27 Specialty pharmaceutical company Akorn Inc will buy rival Hi-Tech Pharmacal Co Inc  for $640 million in cash to expand its eye drug portfolio to other dosage forms such as oral liquids  topical creams and ointments.

column4: Another key factor for stock investors to watch
column5: CHICAGO It's well known that small-company stocks have outperformed large-company stocks in terms of average annualized return since the 1920s  and bargain-priced stocks tend to outperform growth stocks.

column4: U.S. judge wants external monitor for Apple in e-books case
column5: NEW YORK A U.S. judge weighing remedies to assure that Apple Inc does not fix prices again in the e-books market said on Tuesday that she plans to require it to hire an external monitor  something the company considers unnecessary.

column4: Boston mayor reaches deal for Caesars casino at horse racetrack
column5: BOSTON Boston Mayor Thomas Menino reached a proposed deal with developers on Tuesday to build a $1 billion Caesars casino in the city's East Boston section that he said would generate at least $32 million in annual revenue for the city and create thousands of jobs.

column5: Video recorder pioneer TiVo Inc posted a quarterly profit as it gained $490 million from a patent litigation settlement with Google Inc's Motorola Mobility and Cisco Systems Inc.

column4: Facebook says countries sought data on 38 000 users in first half of 2013
column5: SAN FRANCISCO Governments sought information on over 38 000 Facebook users in the first half of 2013 and the No.1 social network complied with most requests  the firm said in its first report on the scale of data inquiries it gets from countries around the world.

column4: Sirius XM sued for digital royalty underpayment
column5: Aug 26 A U.S. nonprofit charged with collecting digital royalties for music artists sued satellite radio service provider Sirius XM Radio Inc for at least $50 million on Monday for underpaying on recordings  including ones from before 1972.

column4: Government mortgage fraud lawsuit against BofA headed to trial
column5: NEW YORK A U.S. government lawsuit accusing Bank of America Corp  of fraud in the sale of billions of dollars of toxic mortgage loans to Fannie Mae  and Freddie Mac  is on track to go to trial next month after a judge rejected the bank's bid to dismiss the case.

column4: Bank of America fails to end U.S. govt's mortgage fraud lawsuit
column5: NEW YORK  Aug 27 Bank of America Corp  failed to persuade a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit in which the United States accused it of causing taxpayers more than $1 billion of losses by selling thousands of toxic mortgage loans to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac

column4: Court reverses ruling on Sentinel loan in blow to BNY Mellon
column5: CHICAGO Bank of New York Mellon Corp  may have to get in line behind former customers of Sentinel Management Group who are seeking to recoup money lost in the futures broker's 2007 collapse  a U.S. appeals court ruled on Monday.

column4: Scotiabank  BMO domestic strength offsets international weakness
column5: TORONTO Bank of Nova Scotia  and Bank of Montreal  kicked off the reporting season for Canadian banks on Tuesday with slightly stronger-than-expected results that highlighted the resilience of their domestic franchises but weakness in international operations.

column4: UPDATE 1-Scotiabank raises dividend as profit just tops estimates
column5: TORONTO  Aug 27 Bank of Nova Scotia  posted a slightly stronger-than-expected quarterly profit and raised its dividend on Tuesday  as it benefited from higher international income as well as its acquisition last year of ING Groep's Canadian online bank.

column4: Barnes & Noble's retail head sells shares
column5: Aug 26 Barnes & Noble Inc's retail group head Mitchell Klipper sold about two-thirds of his shares in the beleaguered retailer in the past few days  according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

column4: Pipeline company seeks more flexible natgas use for electricity
column5: NEW YORK  Aug 27 Gulf South Pipeline Company LP  a unit of Boardwalk Pipeline Partners LP  has filed with energy regulators to provide power generators more flexibility to take gas out of storage during summer months  underscoring how the growing supply of the fuel continues to structurally redesign the electric-power market.

column4: Japan's ANA to buy 49 percent in Myanmar's Asian Wings Airways: source
column5: TOKYO Japan's ANA Holdings Inc  will buy a 49 percent stake in Myanmar carrier Asian Wings Airways as part of a strategy to expand overseas by investing in airline related businesses  an industry source familiar with the agreement said.

column4: France's Total to buy Chevron's Egypt retail network
column5: CAIRO French oil major Total  said it had agreed to buy the Egyptian retail network of U.S. energy company Chevron   in a move it said would create its biggest marketing and services subsidiary outside Europe.

column4: UPDATE 1-France's Total to buy Chevron's Egypt retail network

column5: CAIRO  Aug 27 French oil major Total  said it had agreed to buy the Egyptian retail network of U.S. energy company Chevron  in a move that it says will create its biggest marketing and services subsidiary outside Europe.

column4: Citigroup  J.P.Morgan snare $764 million of California GOs
column5: SAN FRANCISCO Citigroup  and J.P.Morgan Securities  placed winning bids on Tuesday for a $764 million mix of tax-exempt new money and refunding general obligation debt issued by California in a competitive sale.

column4: Ackman turns back on J.C. Penney  sells entire stake in retailer
column5: Hedge fund manager William Ackman  the biggest shareholder in J.C. Penney Co Inc   said on Monday he had sold his entire stake after his campaign to overhaul the retailer failed. | Video

column4: RLPC: Cooper Tire acq. threatened by falling rupee  workers strike
column5: NEW YORK  Aug 27 An emerging market one-two punch threatens to derail a $2.5 billion debt financing package backing the acquisition of U.S.-based Cooper Tire & Rubber Co  by India's Apollo Tyres Ltd  sources told Thomson Reuters LPC.

column4: Entergy focus under new CEO may shift to New York nuclear fight
column5: HOUSTON Entergy Corp's  decision to shut its Vermont nuclear plant begins the final chapter in a battle with politicians seeking to close the station and may shift the firm's focus to the larger Indian Point nuclear plant in New York.

column4: Entergy focus under new CEO may shift to New York nuclear fight

column4: UPDATE 3-Entergy to shut controversial Vermont nuclear plant
column5: HOUSTON/BOSTON  Aug 27 Entergy Corp will shut the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant  citing high costs tied to regulation and competition from cheap natural gas  bringing to an end a long battle with politicians and environmentalists seeking to close it.

column4: Entergy CEO says nuclear industry hit by capital costs  low prices
column5: HOUSTON Running the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant is no longer economical because capital costs rose after 9/11 and could spike again following the Fukushima disaster  Entergy Corp's  Chief Executive Leo Denault said on Tuesday.

column4: Entergy CEO says nuclear industry hit by capital costs  low prices

column4: Low gas  power prices force Entergy to shut Vermont nuclear plant
column5: Aug 27 Entergy Corp said it will shut its Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant  becoming the latest casualty of low power prices and utilities preferring cheap natural gas to generate electricity.

column4: OGX struggles as Petronas holds up deal  fields returned
column5: RIO DE JANEIRO/KUALA LUMPUR Shares in OGX Petróleo e Gas Participações SA  fell for the first day in eight on Tuesday as the troubled oil producer abandoned the purchase of several oil exploration licenses and a venture with Malaysia's Petroliam Nasional Bhd seemed at serious risk.

column4: Israel's Gazit-Globe profit falls on one-time expenses
column5: TEL AVIV  Aug 27 Gazit-Globe  Israel's largest real estate investment company  said on Tuesday its quarterly net profit fell sharply due to one-time expenses and a lower fair value gain from investment property and property under development.

column4: U.S. Attorney won't bring criminal or civil case vs Sands
column5: LOS ANGELES The U.S. Attorney's Office in Los Angeles will not bring a criminal or civil case against Las Vegas Sands Corp  following a probe into its failure to file suspicious activity reports related to certain high-rolling gamblers  the office said in a press release on Tuesday.

column4: Lloyds agrees to sell A$371 million loan parcel to Bain's Sankaty  says spokesman
column5: SYDNEY Britain's Lloyds Banking Group  has agreed to sell a A$371 million ($335.74 million) portfolio of loan assets from its Australian unit BOS International Australia to Bain Capital's Sankaty Advisors for an undisclosed price  a Sankaty spokesman said in a statement.

column5: WASHINGTON The Pentagon on Tuesday announced it had reached agreement with United Technologies Corp  to build 38 engines for a sixth batch of Lockheed Martin Corp  F-35 fighter jets  securing discounts of 2.5 percent to 9.6 percent on the engines.
